Constructor Detail

WebServerResponse

protected WebServerResponse()
Method Detail

close

public void close()
Close the connection.

No writing to the the response is possible after close() is called and WebServerConnection.isClosed() will return true.

Note: The connection MAY not be closed immediately. If you require notification of when the conncetion is actually closed, use close(CloseCallback)

close

public void close(WebServerResponse.CloseCallback callback)
Close the connection.

No writing to the the response is possible after close() is called and WebServerConnection.isClosed() will return true.

Closing is by default an asynchronous operation. You may catch when the connection actually closes by supplying the callback.

Parameters:
callback - object to call when the connection is closed.

closeAndRedispatch

public void closeAndRedispatch()
                        throws IOException
Close the connection and redispatch the request to the Web server.

Close the connection and put the request back into the request queue of the Web server. The WebServerRequest.setUri(String) method may be used for this purpose.

If you have set the status code or added any headers to this response, these will be sent with the new request. But if you redispatch after having written to the response it will fail with a INVALID_STATE_ERR.

If WebServerRequest.getUri() is not changed, redispatching the request will bypass any JavaScript event listeners in the next run. If the URI points to a shared file, this file will be served. Otherwise a 404 will be shown to the user.

Throws:
IOException - If data has been written to this response before it is redispatched.

flush

public void flush()
Flush the data in the response.

Flush the data in the response and send them to the client immediately. Used in combination with chunked encoding, where each flush sends a chunk to the client.

flush

public void flush(WebServerResponse.FlushCallback callback)
Flush the data in the response.

Flush the data in the response and send them to the client immediately. Used in combination with chunked encoding, where each flush sends a chunk to the client.

Flushing is by default an asynchronous operation. You may catch when the the response is actually flushed by supplying an optional callback parameter.

Parameters:
callback - the object to be called when the flush happens

getConnection

public WebServerConnection getConnection()
Retrieves the connection this response will be sent back over

Returns:
connection to the client

isImplicitFlush

public boolean isImplicitFlush()
Whether or not to flush data written to the response automatically.

By default, you need to explicitly call response.flush() in order to actually send data written to the response. Use setImplicitFlush(boolean) to true, so that data is flushed immediately when it's written.

Returns:
true if data should be sent immediately to the client when written

setImplicitFlush

public void setImplicitFlush(boolean value)
Set whether or not to flush data written to the response automatically. (See isImplicitFlush())

Parameters:
value - the value for the implicit flush flag

isClosed

public boolean isClosed()
Whether or not this response has been closed.

This property mirrors the WebServerConnection.isClosed() property.

Returns:
true if the connection underneath this response has been closed

isChunked

public boolean isChunked()
Whether or not chunked encoding is currently being used.

Returns:
true if chunked encoding is being used

setChunked

public void setChunked(boolean value)
Set whether or not to use chunked encoding in the response. (see isChunked()

Chunked encoding is used when you don't know the length of the encoding when starting to send data and to avoid frequently closing and reopening connections. It is only recommended to turn this off if clients are not expected to support chunked encoding.

Defaults to true.

Parameters:
value - the value to set the chunked encoding flag to

setProtocolString

public void setProtocolString(java.lang.String protocolString)
                       throws IOException
Set the protocol version string of the response.

Usually the protocol version string will contain a version of HTTP, but it can be used to set other protocols as well.

Note that you must set a protocol string before you start writing to the response. Failure to do so will result in an IOException.

Parameters:
protocolString - Protocol to use in the response
Throws:
IOException - if data has been written to the response before setting the protocol string.

setHeader

public void setHeader(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String value)
Set a HTTP response header.

Use this method to specify response headers sent back to the client. For example setting the content type to XML, by doing: response.setHeader( "Content-type", "text/html" );

Note that you must set any headers before you start writing to the response. Failure to do so will result in an IOException.

Parameters:
name - Name of the HTTP response header to set, e.g. "Content-type"
value - Value to set for the given HTTP response header.
Throws:
IOException - If data has been written to the response before setting any headers.

setStatusCode

public void setStatusCode(int statusCode)
Set the HTTP status code of the response.

If you do not set a status code, a 200 (OK) status code is silently set.

Note that you must set any status before you start writing to the response. Failure to do so will result in an IOException.

Parameters:
statusCode - Status code to set, e.g. 200 or 404
Throws:
IOException - If data has been written to the response before setting the status code.

setStatusCode

public void setStatusCode(int statusCode,
                          java.lang.String text)
Set the HTTP status code of the response with the give status text. (See setStatusCode(int)

If you do not set a status code, a 200 (OK) status code is silently set.

Note that you must set any status before you start writing to the response. Failure to do so will result in an IOException.

Parameters:
statusCode - Status code to set, e.g. SC_OK or SC_NOT_FOUND
text - Status text to set, e.g. "Success" or "Out of pidgeons".
Throws:
IOException - If data has been written to the response before setting the status code.

write

public void write(java.lang.String data)
Write data to the response.

Parameters:
data - String of data to write.

writeBytes

public void writeBytes(byte[] data)
Write binary data to the response. TODO : Fix the type used in this method!

Parameters:
data - Binary data to write

writeFile

public void writeFile(File file)
Write a File to the response.

This methods takes a File object and writes the contents of the file to the response.

Parameters:
file - File object to write

writeImage

public void writeImage(com.google.gwt.dom.client.ImageElement image)
Write an image to the response.

The image or data referenced is serialized and written to the response, encoded as a PNG image.

Parameters:
image - HTML Image element to write.

writeLine

public void writeLine(java.lang.String data)
Write data to the response and append a newline.

Parameters:
data - String of data to write.
